ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Displays all optional output except plots. When the input data set is TYPE=CORR, 
TYPE=UCORR, TYPE=COV, TYPE=UCOV, or TYPE=FACTOR, simple statistics, correlations, 
and MSA are not displayed.

[Syntax: ALPHA=α] 
      
Specifies the level of confidence 1 - α for interval construction. 
By default, α= 0.05, corresponding to 1 - α= 95% confidence intervals.

[Syntax: CONVERGE=p] 
      
Specifies the convergence criterion for the METHOD=PRINIT, METHOD=ULS, METHOD=ALPHA, 
or METHOD=ML option.
Displays the correlation matrix or partial correlation matrix.

Requests factoring of the covariance matrix instead of the correlation matrix. The COV option is effective
only with the METHOD=PRINCIPAL, METHOD=PRINIT, METHOD=ULS, or METHOD=IMAGE option.

[Syntax: COVER <=p>] 
      
Computes the confidence intervals and optionally specifies the value of factor loading
for coverage detection. By default, p = 0.

[Syntax: DATA=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies the input data set, which can be an ordinary SAS data set or a specially
structured SAS data set. If the DATA= option is omitted, the most recently created 
SAS data set is used.

Displays the eigenvectors of the reduced correlation matrix, of which the diagonal 
elements are replaced with the communality estimates.

[Syntax: FLAG=p] 
      
Flags absolute values larger than p with an asterisk in the correlation and loading matrices.

[Syntax: FUZZ=p] 
      
Prints correlations and factor loadings with absolute values less than p printed 
as missing.

[Syntax: GAMMA=p] 
      
Specifies the orthomax weight used with the option ROTATE=ORTHOMAX or PREROTATE=ORTHOMAX.
Sets to 1 any communality greater than 1, allowing iterations to proceed.

[Syntax: HKPOWER=p] 
      
Specifies the power of the square roots of the eigenvalues used to rescale the 
eigenvectors for Harris-Kaiser (ROTATE=HK) rotation, assuming that the factors 
are extracted by the principal factor method.

[Syntax: MAXITER=n] 
      
Specifies the maximum number of iterations for factor extraction.

Specifies the method for extracting factors. The default is METHOD=PRINCIPAL unless the DATA= data set is TYPE=FACTOR, 
in which case the default is METHOD=PATTERN.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Yields Harris component analysis, a noniterative approximation to canonical component analysis.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Yields principal component analysis of the image covariance matrix, not Kaiser’s or Kaiser and  Rice’s image analysis.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Reads a factor pattern from a TYPE=FACTOR, TYPE=CORR, TYPE=UCORR, TYPE=COV, or TYPE=UCOV data set.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Yields principal component analysis if no PRIORS option or statement is used or if you specify PRIORS=ONE
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Reads scoring coefficients (_TYPE_=’SCORE’) from a TYPE=FACTOR, TYPE=CORR, TYPE=UCORR, TYPE=COV,  or TYPE=UCOV data set.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip9: Produces unweighted least squares factor analysis.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: MINEIGEN=p] 
      
Specifies the smallest eigenvalue for which a factor is retained.

Produces the partial correlations between each pair of variables controlling for 
all other variables (the negative anti-image correlations) and Kaiser’s measure 
of sampling adequacy.

[Syntax: NFACTORS=n] 
      
Specifies the maximum number of factors to be extracted and determines the amount
of memory to be allocated for factor matrices.

[Syntax: NOBS=n] 
      
Specifies the number of observations. If the DATA= input data set is a raw data set, 
nobs is defined by default to be the number of observations in the raw data set.

Prevents the correlation matrix from being transferred to the OUTSTAT= data set 
when you specify the METHOD=PATTERN option.
Omits the intercept from the analysis; covariances or correlations are not corrected for the mean.

Suppresses the display of all output. Note that this option temporarily disables the 
Output Delivery System (ODS).

Turns off the default row normalization of the prerotated factor pattern, which is used in 
computing the promax target matrix.
Specifies the method for normalizing the rows of the factor pattern for rotation.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: The rows of the pattern matrix are rescaled to represent covariances instead of correlations.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Uses Kaiser’s normalization. This is the default.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: The rows are weighted by the Cureton-Mulaik technique.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: NPLOTS= | NPLOT=n] 
      
Specifies the number of factors to be plotted. The default is to plot all factors. 
The smallest allowable value is 2.

[Syntax: OUT=SAS-data-set] 
      
Creates a data set containing all the data from the DATA= data set plus variables
called Factor1, Factor2, and so on, containing estimated factor scores.

[Syntax: OUTSTAT=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies an output data set containing most of the results of the analysis.

[Syntax: PARPREFIX=name] 
      
Specifies the prefix for the residual variables in the OUT= and the OUTSTAT=
data sets when partial variables are specified in the PARTIAL statement.

Plots the factor pattern after rotation. This option produces printer plots. High-quality
ODS graphical plots for factor patterns can be requested with the PLOTS=LOADINGS or 
PLOTS=INITLOADINGS option.
Plots the reference structure instead of the default factor pattern after oblique rotation.

Specifies one or more ODS graphical plots in PROC FACTOR.
      
Syntax: 
(1) PLOTS <(global-plot-options)> = plot-request <(options)> |
(2) PLOTS <(global-plot-options)> = (plot-request <(options)> <...plot-request <(options)> > )

The following are the available global-plot-options or options for plots: 

  CIRCLE | CIRCLES < = numbers > 
  specifies circles with prescribed areas to be drawn in scatter plots or vector plots, where the
  optional numbers represent proportions or percentages of areas enclosed by the circles in the plots.
  These numbers must lie between 0 and 100, inclusively.

  FLIP 
  switches the X and Y axes. It applies to the INITLOADINGS, LOADINGS, and PRELOADINGS plot-requests.

  PLOTREF 
  plots the reference structures rather than the factor pattern loadings. It applies to the
  INITLOADINGS, LOADINGS, and PRELOADINGS plot-requests when the factor solution is oblique.

  UNPACK 
  plots component graphs separately. It applies to the SCREE plot-request only. 

  VECTOR 
  plots loadings in vector form. It applies to the INITLOADINGS, LOADINGS, and PRELOADINGS 
  plot-requests when the factor solution is orthogonal.

[Syntax: POWER=n] 
      
Specifies the power to be used in computing the target pattern for the option 
ROTATE=PROMAX. Valid values must be integers . The default value is 3.

[Syntax: PREFIX=name] 
      
Specifies a prefix for naming the factors. By default, the names are Factor1, 
Factor2, ..., Factorn.

Plots the factor pattern before rotation. This option produces printer plots. High-quality 
ODS graphical plots for factor patterns can be requested with the PLOTS=PRELOADINGS 
option.

[Syntax: PREROTATE=name] 
      
Specifies the prerotation method for the option ROTATE=PROMAX.

Displays the input factor pattern or scoring coefficients and related statistics. 
In oblique cases, the reference and factor structures are computed and displayed. 
The PRINT option is effective only with the option METHOD=PATTERN or METHOD=SCORE.
Specifies a method for computing prior communality estimates.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Sets the prior communality estimates proportional to the squared multiple correlations but adjusted so that their sum is equal to that of the maximum absolute correlations.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Reads the prior communality estimates from the first observation with either _TYPE_=’PRIORS’  or _TYPE_=’COMMUNAL’ in the DATA= data set (which cannot be TYPE=DATA).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Sets the prior communality estimate for each variable to its maximum absolute correlation  with any other variable.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Sets the prior communality estimates to pseudo-random numbers uniformly distributed between 0 and 1.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Sets the prior communality estimate for each variable to its squared multiple correlation with all other variables.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
[Syntax: PROPORTION=p] 
      
Specifies the proportion of common variance to be accounted for by the retained factors.

[Syntax: RANDOM=n] 
      
Specifies a positive integer as a starting value for the pseudo-random number generator
for use with the option PRIORS=RANDOM.

[Syntax: RCONVERGE=p] 
      
Specifies the convergence criterion for rotation cycles.
Causes the rows (variables) of various factor matrices to be reordered on the output.
Displays the residual correlation matrix and the associated partial correlation matrix.

[Syntax: RITER=n] 
      
Specifies the maximum number of cycles n for factor rotation.
Specifies the rotation method. The default is ROTATE=NONE.

ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip1: Specifies orthogonal biquartimax rotation. This corresponds to the specification ROTATE=ORTHOMAX(.5).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip2: Specifies orthogonal equamax rotation. This corresponds to the specification  ROTATE=ORTHOMAX with GAMMA=number of factors/2.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip3: Specifies orthogonal factor parsimax rotation. This corresponds to the specification ROTATE=ORTHOMAX with GAMMA=number of variables.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip4: Specifies that no rotation be performed, leaving the original orthogonal solution.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip5: Specifies the orthogonal Crawford-Ferguson rotation with the weights p1 and p2 for variable parsimony and factor parsimony, respectively.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip6: Specifies the orthogonal generalized Crawford-Ferguson rotation with the four weights p1, p2, p3, and p4.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip7: Specifies the orthomax rotation with orthomax weight p. If ROTATE=ORTHOMAX is used, the default p value is 1 unless specified otherwise in the GAMMA= option.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip8: Specifies orthogonal parsimax rotation. This corresponds to the specification  ROTATE=ORTHOMAX.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip9: Specifies orthogonal quartimax rotation. This corresponds to the specification ROTATE=ORTHOMAX(0).
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip10: Specifies orthogonal varimax rotation. This corresponds to the specification ROTATE=ORTHOMAX with GAMMA=1.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip11: Specifies biquartimin rotation. It corresponds to the specification ROTATE=OBLIMIN(.5) or ROTATE=OBLIMIN with TAU=0.5.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip12: Specifies covarimin rotation. It corresponds to the specification ROTATE=OBLIMIN(1) or ROTATE=OBLIMIN with TAU=1.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip13: Specifies Harris-Kaiser case II orthoblique rotation.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip17: Specifies the oblique Crawford-Ferguson rotation with the weights p1 and p2 for  variable parsimony and factor parsimony, respectively.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip18: Specifies the oblique generalized Crawford-Ferguson rotation with the four weights p1, p2, p3, and p4.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip19: Specifies the oblimin rotation with oblimin weight p.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip21: Specifies oblique quartimax rotation. This is the same as the QUARTIMIN method.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip23: Specifies oblique Procrustes rotation with the target pattern provided by the TARGET= data set.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip24: Specifies oblique promax rotation. You can use the PREROTATE= option to set the desirable prerotation method, orthogonal or oblique.
ProcedureOptionToolTips.@ToolTip25: Specifies quartimin rotation. It is the same as the oblique quartimax method.

ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata: Prints correlation and loading matrices with entries multiplied by 100 and rounded to the nearest integer.
Displays the factor scoring coefficients.
Displays a scree plot of the eigenvalues.

Computes standard errors for various classes of unrotated and rotated solutions under the maximum
likelihood estimation.
Displays means, standard deviations, and the number of observations.

[Syntax: SINGULAR=p] 
      
Specifies the singularity criterion, where 0 < p < 1. The default value is 1E-8.

[Syntax: TARGET=SAS-data-set] 
      
Specifies an input data set containing the target pattern for Procrustes rotation.

[Syntax: TAU=p] 
      
Specifies the oblimin weight used with the option ROTATE=OBLIMIN or PREROTATE=OBLIMIN.
Allows communalities to exceed 1.
Specifies the divisor to use in the calculation of variances and covariances. The default value is VARDEF=DF.

Factors a weighted correlation or covariance matrix. The WEIGHT option can be used 
only with the METHOD=PRINCIPAL, METHOD=PRINIT, METHOD=ULS, or METHOD=IMAGE option.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: BY <DESCENDING> variable-1 <...<DESCENDING> variable-n> <NOTSORTED>; 
      
You can specify a BY statement with PROC FACTOR to obtain separate analyses on 
observations in groups that are defined by the BY variables. When a BY statement 
appears, the procedure expects the input data set to be sorted in order of the BY 
variables. If you specify more than one BY statement, only the last one specified 
is used.

StatementOptionHelp.#cdata:
Specifies that the observations are sorted in descending order by the variable that 
immediately follows the word DESCENDING in the BY statement.
Specifies that observations are not necessarily sorted in alphabetic or numeric order.

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: FREQ variable;
      
If a variable in the data set represents the frequency of occurrence for the other values 
in the observation, include the variable’s name in a FREQ statement. The procedure then 
treats the data set as if each observation appears n times, where n is the value of the FREQ 
variable for the observation. The total number of observations is considered to be equal to 
the sum of the FREQ variable when the procedure determines degrees of freedom for significance
probabilities. 

If the value of the FREQ variable is missing or is less than one, the observation is not 
used in the analysis. If the value is not an integer, the value is truncated to an integer. 

The WEIGHT and FREQ statements have a similar effect, except in determining the number of 
observations for significance tests.

Syntax: WEIGHT variable;
      
If you want to use relative weights for each observation in the input data set, 
specify a variable containing weights in a WEIGHT statement. This is often done 
when the variance associated with each observation is different and the values 
of the weight variable are proportional to the reciprocals of the variances. If 
a variable value is negative or is missing, it is excluded from the analysis.

Syntax: PRIORS communalities ;
      
The PRIORS statement specifies numeric values between 0.0 and 1.0 for the prior 
communality estimates for each variable. The first numeric value corresponds to 
the first variable in the VAR statement, the second value to the second variable, 
and so on. The number of numeric values must equal the number of variables.
